channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Three Al Jazeera Journalists Remain in Jail After Egyptian Court Orders a Retrial
item.description: The television reporters, jailed on charges of aiding the Muslim Brotherhood, will remain in custody while awaiting a new trial.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:credit: Heba Elkholy/El Shorouk, via Associated Press
item.media:description: From left, the Al Jazeera journalists Baher Mohamed, Mohammed Fahmy and Peter Greste during their trial last year in Cairo.

item.title: Ebola Doctors Are Divided on IV Therapy in Africa
item.description: Doctors seeking to stem the Ebola epidemic disagree on whether most patients in West Africa should, or can, be given intravenous hydration, a standard therapy in developed countries.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: A nurse gave an Ebola patient intravenous fluids at the Red Cross treatment center in Kenema, Sierra Leone, in November.

item.title: Antakya Journal: Vanguard of Syria’s Uprising, Now on the Run From ISIS, Weighs a Bleak Future
item.description: Syrian fighters and activists who once gathered in southern Turkey to plan a revolution are now marooned, their hopes rapidly deflating.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Looking over Antakya, Turkey. Once a hub for Syrian rebels trying to depose President Bashar al-Assad, the city later became a way station for foreign jihadists.

item.title: Cuba Again Arrests Artist Seeking Dissidents’ Release
item.description: Tania Bruguera, who advocates free speech in her native country, was arrested for the third time in two days.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Joining International Criminal Court Wouldn’t Guarantee Palestinians a War Crimes Case
item.description: Even if the Palestinian Authority becomes a member of the International Criminal Court, the legal repercussions from the Gaza war last summer would take longer to resolve and face many hurdles.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: An Israeli strike in Gaza City on July 29, 2014. Legal repercussions from the war last summer would face many hurdles.

item.title: President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil Begins 2nd Term Vowing to Fight Graft
item.description: Ms. Rousseff’s narrow victory in October and the weakening of her governing coalition among lawmakers will make it harder for her to tackle the challenges she faces, experts said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil, who was narrowly re-elected, during her inauguration on Thursday in Brasília.

item.title: World Briefing: The Philippines: Blaze Destroys a Slum
item.description: A huge blaze believed to have been ignited by firecrackers razed nearly a thousand shanties and killed three people in a slum near the capital, Manila.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: 8 Wounded in Church Bombing
item.description: A suicide bomber blew himself up at the gates of a church in the northeastern city of Gombe during a New Year’s Day service, wounding eight people.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: France: Hundreds of Cars Set on Fire
item.description: The Interior Ministry said Thursday that 940 cars were set on fire by vandals on New Year’s Eve, fewer than the 1,067 set aflame the previous year.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Kenya: Soldiers Ambushed by Gunmen
item.description: Gunmen attacked a truck carrying Kenyan soldiers near the border with Somalia on Thursday, seriously wounding three of them, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Civilian Deaths Increase in 2014
item.description: Violence in Iraq killed more than 15,000 civilians and security personnel in 2014, according to government figures issued Thursday, making it one of the deadliest years since the American-led invasion in 2003.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: Web Freedom Is Seen to Be Growing as a Global Issue in 2015
item.description: The new year promises further attempts at online censorship, as the web increasingly serves as a platform for civil rights efforts.
item.dc:creator: By VINDU GOEL and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Supporters of anti-corruption figure Aleksei Navalny in Moscow. The government had Facebook block a page on a planned rally, but copycat pages popped up.

item.title: China’s Economy Faces Sluggish Start for New Year
item.description: Data indicate that Beijing may have to resort to more stimulus measures to avert job losses and debt default in the world’s second-largest economy.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Despite Thaw, American Base at Guantánamo Still Stings for Cubans
item.description: Despite a sudden improvement in relations between the United States and Cuba, the base at Guantánamo remains a sore point for Cubans.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Harry Henry, 85, was one of the last Cubans to work at the Guantánamo naval base. He retired in 2012. Most Cubans, even opponents of the government, want the base returned.

item.title: To Rescue Economy, Japan Turns to Supermom
item.description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe pledged to make it easier for women who have children to continue careers, rather than leaving the work force.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chiaki Kitajima, who is the creative director at an advertising agency, picking up her youngest son, Daido, at a child care center.

item.title: In Moments, New Year’s Revelry Became Fatal Crush in Shanghai
item.description: Most of the 36 victims were young revelers who had come to ring in 2015 on the Bund, the city’s iconic riverfront promenade.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:description: Revelers caught in a stampede during a New Year’s Eve celebration on the Bund, a waterfront promenade in Shanghai.

item.title: Turkish Police Thwart Attack on Prime Minister’s Office in Istanbul
item.description: The police arrested a man who tried to attack a palace complex close to the prime minister’s office in Istanbul, throwing two homemade grenades that failed to detonate.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: ‘A Kim Jong-il Production’ Looks at North Korea’s Film Past
item.description: Paul Fischer, the author of the coming book “A Kim Jong-il Production,” talks about “The Interview” and North Korea’s own brand of moviemaking.
item.dc:creator: By ALEXANDRA ALTER
item.media:description: A scene from “Pulgasari,” a film made by the South Korean director Shin Sang-ok while he was held captive in North Korea.

item.title: Syria Deaths in 2014 Hit a New High, Group Says
item.description: Figures compiled by the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights showed 76,021 people had died in the Syria conflict in 2014.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and MOHAMMAD GHANNAM
item.media:description: Carrying milk for sale in the Old City of Aleppo, Syria. A monitoring group said over 3,500 children were among more than 76,000 civil war fatalities in 2014.

item.title: Digital Tax Increase to Take Effect in Europe
item.description: New rules are coming into force for services like movie streaming and content like e-books on Thursday, but who will foot most of the bill remains unclear.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT
